thread.title: Newcastle firm owned by Brexit campaigner Arron Banks facing massive fine

author: Graeme Whitfield
title: Newcastle firm owned by Brexit campaigner Arron Banks facing massive fine
text:
Newcastle firm owned by Brexit campaigner Arron Banks facing massive fine Eldon Insurance facing fine over data protection breaches linked to the EU referendum Share Get business
A Newcastle company owned by Brexit campaigner Arron Banks has been warned it faces a £60,000 fine for data protection breaches.
The Information Commissioner’s Office (ICO) said it had issued “notices of intent” to Eldon Insurance and to the Leave.EU campaign for “serious breaches” of Privacy and Electronic Communications Regulations.
It followed the discovery of evidence that some Eldon customers’ personal data had been used by Leave.EU to unlawfully distribute political marketing messages, the ICO said.
It included the sending of almost 330,000 emails to customers of Eldon Insurance - trading as GoSkippy - containing a Leave.EU newsletter, for which the campaign group faces a £15,000 fine.
The ICO also warned that Leave.EU and the insurance company face fines of £60,000 each in relation to the sending of more than 1m emails to Leave.EU subscribers which included GoSkippy marketing material.
Eldon Insurance is registered in Bristol with Mr Banks’ other companies, but has its biggest base in Newcastle. Read More North East voters want a second Brexit referendum, according to major opinion poll
The details were released as the Information Commissioner, Elizabeth Denham, was presenting the ICO’s findings to MPs at a hearing of the Commons Digital, Culture, Media and Sport Committee.
In its final report on the use of data analytics in political campaigning, the ICO also disclosed that it would have issued Cambridge Analytica - the company at the centre of the Facebook data breach - with a “substantial fine” if it had not gone into administration.
Eldon Insurance said that it had only received the “notice of intent” from the ICO at 4pm on Monday and would be making representations concerning its findings. Read More
